citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee has recently acquired an adult female Bichon and does not have the necessary equipment to groom this
dog. The dog has heavily matted fur on all four legs and tail. The licensee stated that she plans to groom the dog and will
acquire the necessary equipment to do so in the next few days. This breed of dog requires regular grooming, and
although recently acquired by the licensee, the dog appears to not have been groomed for several months. Having the
appropriate equipment to conduct regular grooming is important to allow daily observation of the dogs and to maintain
their skin and coat health. The licensee must acquire the necessary equipment to provide appropriate grooming for all the
breeds present at the facility.
To be corrected by 12-21-24

In one enclosure housing 3 adult dogs there is an overturned water bowl and no other access to potable water provided.
The licensee stated that the bowl has to be filled multiple times because the dogs overturn the water frequently. Dogs that
do not have access to water may experience thirst or become dehydrated. The licensee need to provide continuous
access to potable water.
To be corrected by 12-20-24

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The sheltered portion of one primary primary enclosure housing three adult dogs is heavily contaminated with fecal
material. The fecal material has been flattened and smeared across the floor when the dogs walk through it and covers
approximately 80% of the floor. Failure to provide adequate cleaning and sanitization in the primary enclosures increases
the risk of disease transmission, attracts insects/pests, and increases odors. Excreta could potentially cause soiling on the
body of the dog being housed in the affected enclosure. The licensee must remove excreta and food waste from the
primary enclosure daily and from under the primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent an excessive
accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the dogs contained in the primary enclosures, and to reduce
disease hazards, insects, pests and odors.
To be corrected by 12-20-24
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(1) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee has recently acquired an adult female Bichon and does not have the necessary equipment to groom this 
dog. The dog has heavily matted fur on all four legs and tail. The licensee stated that she plans to groom the dog and will 
acquire the necessary equipment to do so in the next few days. This breed of dog requires regular grooming, and 
although recently acquired by the licensee, the dog appears to not have been groomed for several months. Having the 
appropriate equipment to conduct regular grooming is important to allow daily observation of the dogs and to maintain 
their skin and coat health. The licensee must acquire the necessary equipment to provide appropriate grooming for all the 
breeds present at the facility. 
To be corrected by 12-21-24 
3.10(a) 
   
Watering 
In one enclosure housing 3 adult dogs there is an overturned water bowl and no other access to potable water provided. 
The licensee stated that the bowl has to be filled multiple times because the dogs overturn the water frequently. Dogs that 
do not have access to water may experience thirst or become dehydrated. The licensee need to provide continuous 
access to potable water. 
To be corrected by 12-20-24 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The sheltered portion of one primary primary enclosure housing three adult dogs is heavily contaminated with fecal 
material. The fecal material has been flattened and smeared across the floor when the dogs walk through it and covers 
approximately 80% of the floor. Failure to provide adequate cleaning and sanitization in the primary enclosures increases 
the risk of disease transmission, attracts insects/pests, and increases odors. Excreta could potentially cause soiling on the 
body of the dog being housed in the affected enclosure. The licensee must remove excreta and food waste from the 
primary enclosure daily and from under the primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent an excessive 
accumulation of feces and food waste, to prevent soiling of the dogs contained in the primary enclosures, and to reduce 
disease hazards, insects, pests and odors. 
To be corrected by 12-20-24

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
